titleStmt.title: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T A Survey of Teaching-Learning-Based Optimization

analytic.title: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T A Survey of Teaching-Learning-Based Optimization

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Over past few decades, swarm intelligent algorithms based on the intelligent behaviors of social creatures have been extensively studied and applied for all kinds of optimization areas. Teaching-learning-based optimization (TLBO) algorithm which imitates the teaching-learning process in a classroom, is one of population-based heuristic stochastic swarm intelligent algorithms. TLBO executes through similar iterative evolution processes as utilized by a standard evolutionary algorithm. Unlike traditional evolutionary algorithms and swarm intelligent algorithms, the iterative computation process of TLBO is divided into two phases and each phase executes iterative learning operation. Since its introduction by Rao and his team in 2010, TLBO has attracted more and more researchers' attention because of some of its strengths such as simple concept, without algorithm-specific parameters, rapid convergence and easy implementation yet effectiveness. In this paper we attempt to provide a brief review of the basic concepts of TLBO and a comprehensive survey of its prominent variants and its typical application, and the theoretical analysis conducted on TLBO so far. We hope that this survey can be very beneficial for the researchers engaged in the study of TLBO.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: In the past few years, with rapid incensement of real-world optimization problems in various fields of science, there is an urgent need for effective and efficient optimization methods to deal with these increasingly complex optimization problems. Early works mainly focused on all kinds of mathematical techniques. However, most of those methods have often failed to find optimal solutions due to falling into local optimum. Therefore, the development of new meta-heuristic algorithms for optimization has become a hotspot in artificial intelligence during the last decades [1,2]. This has prompted more and more and researchers to develop a large amount of different meta-heuristic algorithms, such as evolutionary algorithms (EAs), swarm intelligence algorithms (SIs) and meta-heuristic algorithms based on abiological phenomena. Evolutionary algorithms are based on Darwinian concepts of natural evolution of the living beings and survival of the fittest individuals in Nature, and they comprise of a whole family of techniques such as Genetic Algorithm (GA) [3], Evolutionary Programming (EP) [4], Evolution Strategies (ES) [5], Genetic Programming (GP) [6], Differential Evolution (DE) [7,8] and so on.

Swarm intelligence algorithms (SIs) are based on the collective behavior of decentralized and self-organized swarms, and they also comprise of a whole family of techniques such as Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) [9 10], Ant Colony Optimization (ACO) [11,12], Biogeography-Based Optimization (BBO) [13,14], Artificial Bee Colony (ABC) [15,16] and so on. The meta-heuristic algorithms based on abiological phenomena include the

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: Gravitational Search Algorithm (GSA) [17], Artificial Raindrop Algorithm (ARA) [18], Water Evaporation Optimization (WEO) [19], Electromagnetic field optimization (EFO) [20] and so on. However, there are some user-defined algorithm-specific control parameters in these previous mentioned algorithms except for basic parameters such as population size and generation number (or function evaluations). For example, GA uses the mutation rate and crossover rate, and DE uses the scaling factor F and the crossover rate Cr. These algorithm-specific parameters need to be reasonably set and proper tuning, and it is essential for the searching ability of these algorithms. Hence, the efforts must be continued to develop an optimization algorithm without algorithm-specific parameters.

Teaching-learning-based optimization (TLBO) algorithm was originally introduced by Rao et al [21,22] in 2011, and it is inspired from the philosophy of the teaching-learning process in a classroom and mimics the influence of a teacher on the output of learners. Similar to other swarm intelligence algorithms (SIs), TLBO is a population-based heuristic stochastic optimization algorithm, but it does not require any algorithm-specific parameters. Due to TLBO's some characters such as simple concept, without algorithm-specific parameters, rapid convergence and easy implementation yet effectiveness, it has been successfully extended and widely applied to solve numerous real world problems from diverse fields of science and technology. In order to present the flavor of the huge and multi-faceted literature on TLBO, a short survey by [23] in 2015 only reviewed five TLBO variants taken from Refs. [24][25][26][27][28] for single-objective optimization problems and also compared the performance of these variants on some benchmark test functions. Rao provided a brief review for applications of TLBO in 2016 [29]. However, he only simply listed 200 papers related to TLBO up to the date of publication of his paper, and did not focus on what modifications have been made to the original TLBO and what are the areas of its engineering applications. In this paper, we provide a more comprehensive survey on almost all aspects of the recent advances in TLBO including its basic concepts, modifications based on initialization techniques, adaptive parameters, mutation genetic operations, different learning strategies, population neighborhood and population diversity, and hybridizations with search techniques and population-based optimization algorithms, optimization scenarios and engineering applications in various areas.

The remainders of this paper are organized as follow. Section 2 provides a gentle introduction to the basic concepts and structure related to the original TLBO algorithm and explains the original formulation in the real-value space. Section 3 gives an overview of some prominent TLBO variants based different strategies and techniques. Hybrid TLBO algorithms based on local search methods and other optimization algorithms have been reviewed in Section 4. Section 5 provides an extensive investigation on optimization scenarios of TLBO to constrained, multi-objective and dynamic optimization problems. Section 6 presents an overview on some prominent engineering applications of TLBO. Section 7 highlights some future research works related to TLBO.
Finally, the paper is concluded in Section 8.

div.head: Teaching-learning-based optimization
div.p: Teaching-learning-based optimization algorithm (TLBO) is a population-based heuristic stochastic

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: optimization algorithm inspired from the teaching-learning process in a classroom [21,22]. In the TLBO algorithm, learners are regarded as search points distributed in the decision variable space and they correspond to the population of solutions in EAs and SIs. The learner with the best fitness is defined as the teacher of the class.

Unlike traditional EAs and SIs, the iterative evolution process of TLBO includes the teaching phase and the learning phase (Seen Fig. 1). To enhance the average knowledge level of the class, learners improve their knowledge levels by learning from the teacher in the teaching phase, and they also improve their knowledge levels by learning interactively from another learner selected randomly in learning phase. The whole working processes of TLBO is explained below.

div.p: During the learning phase, learners also learn interactively through group discussions, presentations and formal communications and so on to increase their knowledge levels. For the i-th learner X i in the class, the

div.head: Modification and Analysis
div.p: Since its introduction in 2011, TLBO has been attracting more and more attention of scholars and engineers from different disciplines of knowledge around the world. Many new ideas from different search techniques and population-based algorithms have been introduced into the original TLBO to improve its optimization performance, and thus various modifications to the original TLBO have been developed to deal with all kinds of optimization problems so far. In the following, a few prominent modifications related to TLBO are reviewed under different subtitles.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M
div.p: A N U S C R I P T

div.head: TLBO with initialization techniques
div.p: All population-based algorithms such as EAs and SIs start with an initial population. Generally, a good initialization method may generate better initial individuals, thus helping algorithms to obtain better final results [30][31][32]. Based on this situation, many new ways of population initialization have been proposed for TLBO.
Opposition-based learning (OBL) presented by Tizhoosh [33] can accelerate the searching speed by retaining the fitter one from an individual to its opposite in the population (Seen Fig. 2).

div.head: Fig.2 Opposition-based learning and quasi-oppositional learning
div.p: In an extended TLBO variant developed by Shao et al [34], a modified Nawaz-Enscore-Ham heuristic method and the opposition-based learning were introduced to generate the initialization population. By introducing quasi-opposition based learning (OBL) into TLBO, Roy et al proposed an oppositional TLBO variant [35]. They randomly generated the entire population of learners within the upper and lower limits and created opposite population of these learners based on OBL, and then select fittest individuals from these two populations as initial population. As well as, many authors also employed quasi-opposition based learning in TLBO to generate the initialization population [36][37][38][39][40][41].

div.head: TLBO with adaptive parameters
div.p: It is common brief that the individuals should explore diverse areas of the search space during the early stages and then should exploit a relatively small search space during the later stages. Based on this intuition, Satapathy et al employed an adaptive weight in TLBO to adaptively adjust the movements of trial learners and control the search areas [42]. In the paper, the value of the weight factor decreased linearly with the number of iterations in the teaching phase and the learning phase as shown in Eq.( 4).
where max min and ww are the maximum and minimum weight, max iteration and iteration are the maximum iterative number and the current iterative number, , respectively.
Similarly, Cao and Luo also adopted the adaptive weight factor to obtain a strong global searching ability as shown Eq.( 5) [43].

div.p: stochastic variations of this difference vector, thus retaining diversity of population during the evolution progresses. The teaching factor was given as shown in Eq.( 6)

To further improve the learning efficiency of learners, Li et al proposed a new ameliorated TLBO variant with the inertia weight and acceleration coefficient [45]. The inertia weight i  adjusted the influence of the previous individual and the acceleration coefficient i  adjusted the learning step size as shown in Eq.( 7).

Bulbul and Roy proposed a new TLBO method with an adaptive dynamic control mechanism for nonlinear economic load dispatch problem [46]. This mechanism is similar to the above weight operation so as to balance between local and global searches during the search processes. The teaching constant in the teaching phase was dynamically adjusted according to fitness values of learners, and the learning constant in the learning phase was adaptively adjusted according to the current generation and the maximum generation. They replaced random value rand in Eq.( 2) and Eq.(3) as shown in Eq.( 8 max iteration and iteration are the maximum iterative number and the current iterative number.

Wu et al developed an improved TLBO algorithm [47]. The nonlinear inertia weighted factor w was nonlinearly increased with the development of iterations to adjust the memory rate of learners and scale the existing knowledge of the learner. The dynamic inertia weighted factor r was a random number in the range [0.5, 1] to increase the probability of random fluctuations and increase the differential increment to the existing learners.
They are given as follows
where max iteration and iteration are the maximum iterative number and the current iterative number, min w is the minimum weight, and rand is a random number within the range [0, 1]

It has been proved that a large population size might be unhelpful in evolutionary algorithms [48]. Based on this concept, Chen at al proposed a novel TLBO approach with variable-population scheme [49]. In the paper, the
div.formula: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: population size varied in the form of a triangle from the minimum to the maximum and then from the maximum to the minimum in a period. When increasing the population size, new individuals were generated according to Gaussian distribution with a designed mean and variance. When decreasing the population size, the individuals were sorted based on their similarity and the most similar individuals were deleted. Sleesongsom and Bureerat presented a new TLBO variant [50]. In the proposed algorithm, a successful solution in the teaching and learning phases was a member in a new population when its fitness value was better than the average value of learners in its parent population. Then, if the average value of successful solutions from the teaching phase was better than that of successful solutions from the learning phase, the population size in the teaching phase will increase while the population size in the learning phase will reduce and vice versa. Yildiz proposed a new hybrid TLBO algorithm with Taguchi's method [51]. To obtain an efficient exploration using a small population by refining the search space, Taguchi's robust parameter design was introduced during the population initialization.

div.head: TLBO with genetic operations
div.p: The mutation operator can generate offspring by randomly changing one or several bits of an individual, and the crossover operator can generate offspring by exchanging some bits in the two individuals [52,53]. They can enhance the exploration ability and maintain the diversity of population, and provide improved search moves on complex optimization problems. Hence, many researchers have introduced mutation operator and the crossover operator into TLBO. To improve the search capability and convergence, García and Mena presented a modified TLBO variant with mutation [54]. In each generation, mutation operations similar to DE algorithm were introduced into the original TLBO. In other words, mutation operator based on DE/rand/1 was employed for the learners after the learning phase in each iteration as shown in Eq.(10). x x x are randomly selected learners from the class and 1 2 3 r r r i    , 1 and 2 rand rand are is two random numbers within the range [0, 1].

Ghasemi et al developed an improved TLBO variant with Lévy mutation strategy [55]. Based on the characteristic of Lévy distribution, the Lévy mutation operator was utilized to improve search performance as shown in Eq.( 11) .

Wang et al introduced a new mutation into TLBO to deal with the duplicate eliminations [56]. When the duplicate solutions exist, the maximum mutation step was calculated based on the lower and upper bounds obtained by check each dimensional range of the design variables. The new learners of the duplicate learners were generated by employing a random vector and the maximum mutation step.

Step is the maximum mutation step and it can be calculated according to the lower and upper bounds of all learners.

Ouyang et al presented a new TLBO variant with global crossover for global optimization problems [57]. To prevent falling into local optima and enhance the exploration ability, a perturbed scheme was integrated into the teaching phase. As well as, the global crossover operation based on binomial crossover with random numbers was integrated into the learning phase. That is, after the learning phase learning strategy of the original TLBO as shown Eq.(3), crossover operation was employed as follows

Shao et al introduced the crossover based on permutations into TLBO [34]. That is, a new pair of learners was generated by perform two-point order crossover between the current learner and other two randomly selected learners different from the current learner. Then the better learner of these two new generated learners will replaced the current learner. Ji et al introduced the mutation and crossover operation into the original TLBO to enhance its exploitation and exploration ability [58]. Inspired by backtracking search optimization algorithm, the historical population was used to store and manage the historical information of the learners, and it can be updated randomly at each iteration. The new population was generated by mutation and crossover operation by using the current and the historical population. Xu et al proposed an effective TLBO approach [59]. In the proposed approach, an effective teaching-learning mechanism based on crossover scheme was introduced into the search framework of TLBO and special local search operators were adopted to improve exploitation capabilities.

div.head: TLBO with learning strategies
div.p: Satapathy et al developed a new TLBO variant with orthogonal design [26]. The orthogonal design (OD) was used to generate optimal offspring learners by a statistical optimal method after the teaching phase and learning phase. In other words, after the teaching phase and learning phase, m (m was set to 6 in proposed approach) learners were selected randomly and each learner can be divided into several partial vectors. Then the OD-based operator was employed to these learners so as to search the m best representative sets of combinations among all the various combinations. Satapathy and Naik extended a new TLBO variant [28]. In the learning phase of this variant, a new term was added to the updating equation. This term represents learner also learned something new from the teacher as shown in Eq.( 14)

Ji et al introduced the self-feedback learning to improve knowledge levels of learners by themselves after the teaching phase [58]. In this new learning phase, the current level of a learner was compare with its previous level stored in the historical population. When the current level of a learner was better than its historical level, it means that the learner has made a progress, and thus the learner would enhance its knowledge level from this learning experience of this progress. The self-feedback learning was given as follows

Niknam et al presented a new multi-objective optimization TLBO algorithm [61]. In the proposed algorithm, after the teaching and learning phases, the target vector of each learner was mixed with the mutated learner which was generated based on a new mutation operator from three different learners selected randomly.
A modified TLBO algorithm was developed by Camp and Farshchin [62]. A fitness-based weighted mean of the class replaced the mean of the class in the teaching phase as shown as follows.
div.formula: NP ij i i j NP i i X fit X Nmean fit X      (21)
div.p: where, () i fit X is the fitness value of the i-th learner X i , NP is the population size.

Zou et al extended a new TLBO variant with learning experience of other learners [63]. In the proposed approach, the random possibilities were used to select the original TLBO learning strategy or the learning method based on the experience of others. In the teaching phase, when the experience of others was adopted, another learner different from the learner was randomly selected from the population. If this selected learner was better than the learner, then the learner learns learning experience of this selected learner; otherwise, the learner learned by using the area copying operator. The learning process can be given as follows

div.p: In order to enhance the overall performance of TLBO, Bi et al proposed a new self-adaptive TLBO algorithm that uses a mixed strategy (MSTLBO) [64]. In the learning phase, adaptive integrated cross learning based on random learning and directional learning was executed adaptively to enhance the searching ability for different evolutionary stages. Then a directional disturbance strategy was adopted to increase the population diversity and avoid falling into local optima. Yang et al introduced a self-learning phase into the original TLBO to further exploit the space near the learner [65]. After the teaching and learning phases, learners will search their local areas by introducing a self-learning weight that determines the self-learning range of each learner. Wang et al proposed a novel TLBO variant (EI-TLBO) with experience information [66]. In EI-TLBO, experience information based on the historical learning experience was introduced to judge its learning behavior in future. Moreover, differential
div.formula: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: mutation learning was introduced to maintain the diversity of population. That is, learners learn knowledge by one learning method selected randomly from experience learning and differential mutation learning. To enhance the exploration and exploitation ability of population, Raja et al proposed a new TLBO variant (TS-TLBO) [67]. In TS-LBO, the tutorial training method was incorporated into the teaching phase and the self-learning method was incorporated into the learning phase. Yu et al developed a self-adaptive multi-objective TLBO approach (SA-MTLBO) [68,69]. In SA-MTLBO, the learning approach of each learner was self-adaptively selected according to its knowledge level at each iteration. The rank of each learner was determined according to its non-domination front rank and crowding distance value, and it determined this learner to employ the teaching phase or learning phase. where, r is the rank of the i-th learner X i , NP is the population size. Then the learning process can be given as

div.head: Employ the teaching phase else
div.p: Employ the learning phase

To improve the convergence performance, the chaotic phase was introduced into the original TLBO by Farah et al [70]. After the teaching and learning phase, a new chaotic phase was employed to generate the new disturbed individual of each existing learner by converting the chaotic variables based on logistic map. To enhance the efficiency of the learning process, a novel fuzzy adaptive TLBO variant (FATLBO) was proposed by Cheng and Prayogo [71,72]. In FATLBO, a status monitor was designed to obtain the success rate of the teaching phase and learning phase by tracking the progress of learners in each phase. Then, a fuzzy logic system was adopted to adjust the probability rate based on this information from the status monitor for determining a learner to employ teaching phase or learning phase. In additional, when the algorithm converges prematurely, a random remedial operator based on Gaussian distribution was utilized to enlarge the search areas of learners. To adaptively select global or local search methods, a fuzzy inference system was introduced into TLBO [73,74]. Here the fuzzy inference system based on quality, intensification and diversification measures was developed to adaptively select the teaching phase or the learning phase.

Cho et al compared TLSO with other algorithms on benchmark test functions to validate and evaluate their performance [75]. Self-study method was introduced to keep a tradeoff between intensification and diversification.

That is, the learning phase learning method in the original TLBO or Self-study method was adopted according to a certain probability. Yu et al developed a self-adaptive TLBO approach (SATLBO) [76]. Similar to SA-MTLBO [68,69], a selecting probability was used to select only one learning phase at each iteration. Moreover, an elite learning strategy was introduced into the teaching phase and a diversity learning method was introduced into and learning phase. In order to prevent a diversity loss of population, the diversity learning was introduced by Yu et al into the original TLBO [77]. In the proposed algorithm, the learner was generated by using crossover operator from three different learners as follows
div.formula: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T 1 2 3 ( ) 0.5 r r r i i x x x if rand newx x otherwise          (26) where i x is the i-th learner in the class, 12 3
div.p: , and r r r
x x x are randomly selected learners from the class and  is a uniformly distributed random number in [-1, 1].

To deal with low convergence precision and premature convergence, an improved self-learning mechanism-based TLBO (SLTLBO) algorithm was proposed by Tong et al [78]. In SLTLBO, learners improved their knowledge levels by learning differences from the teacher and the worst learner in teaching phase.

Meanwhile, the learners performed self-examination learning based on Gaussian searching learning to jump out of the local area. Naik et al introduced the gradient descent learning into TLBO to optimize the weights of functional link higher order artificial neural network model [79]. In addition, the opposite candidate individual may have more opportunities to get closer to the global optimum than a random candidate individual [29], hence the opposition-based learning and quasi-opposition learning were also introduced into TLBO to enhance its convergence speed [33][34][35][36][37][38][39][40][41].

div.head: TLBO with population neighborhood and population diversity
div.p: Generally, the global optimum was near to local optima, and searching neighborhoods of local optima will have more chances to find better solutions. Hence, various neighborhood searching techniques were often utilized to improve the exploration performance of algorithms. To enhance the exploration ability of the population, a ring neighborhood topology (Seen Fig. 3) was introduced into the teaching phase of the original TLBO [56]. Each learner exchanges learning information with its neighbors to search neighborhood space in the teaching phase.

div.head: Fig.3 Ring neighborhood topology with three members
div.p: Chen et al introduced quasi von Neumann neighborhood structure into the original TLBO to improve the global performance of TLBO [80]. Each learner in the learning phase improved knowledge level by using learning phase learning method or new neighborhood learning strategy according to a certain probability. When the neighborhood learning strategy was selected, the learner learns knowledge from its neighboring learner with the best knowledge level as well as another neighboring learner selected randomly.

Multi-population method in population-based optimization algorithms has the advantage that sub-populations can simultaneously explore and search diverse areas in the search space, and hence researchers have developed various multi-population optimization algorithms by using subpopulations to cover different areas in the search space. Inspired by these methods, Zou et al propose an improved TLBO approach with dynamic group strategy [81]. All learners were divided into groups of equal number based on the Euclidean distance between pairs of

div.head: A C C E P T E D M
div.p: A N U S C R I P T learners. Each learner learned from the teacher of the class and the mean of its corresponding group in the teaching phase, and it also improved knowledge level by the quantum-behaved learning strategy or the learning method according to a certain probability (Seen Fig. 4). After a certain number of generations, all learners were re-divided into different groups.

div.head: Divide
div.p: Move Regroup

div.head: Fig.4 Dynamic group strategy
div.p: Zhai et al proposed a new TLBO variant with a fuzzy grouping learning strategy [82]. Fuzzy K-means clustering based on Euclidean distance was introduced to divide learners into small sized groups, and each group utilized its own group members to search a small area in the search space. Reddy proposed a clustered adaptive TLBO approach [83,84]. Learners were partitioned into a certain number of clusters according to their spatial distribution. Each cluster had a teacher with the best fitness, and these clusters improve or optimize separately. Li et al developed an improved TLBO variant with group learning (GTLBO) [85]. In GTLBO, all learners were also randomly divided into several groups. Zou et al proposed a new two-level hierarchical multi-swarm cooperative TLBO variant (HMCTLBO) to maintain the diversity of population and improve the exploration ability of learners [86]. In HMCTLBO, several sub-swarms were constructed by randomly dividing all learners at the bottom layer, and each swarm evolved in parallel independently (Seen Fig. 5). Furthermore, a new swarm was constructed by the best learners from each swarm at the top layer, and this swarm employed Gaussian sampling learning. In addition, all sub-swarms were dynamically regrouped after a certain number of iterations. and Feng proposed an efficient TLBO algorithm combined with multi-population evolutionary strategy for community detection [92]. In addition, Cruz et al presented a parallel TLBO procedure for automatic heliostat aiming [93]. Biswas introduced a modified TLBO technique into different cooperative co-evolutionary framework for solving high dimensional problems [94].

div.head: Hybrid TLBO Algorithms
div.p: A hybrid optimization algorithm integrates two or more search techniques or population-based optimization algorithm into a unique algorithm to form a new algorithm so as to transcend its ancestors. This makes it possible for the hybrid algorithm to take full use of the strengths of these techniques and algorithms while simultaneously overcoming their main limitations [95,96]. In this section, we will investigate the hybrid TLBO algorithms with different search techniques or other optimization algorithms.

div.head: Hybridization of TLBO with search techniques
div.p: A few prominent hybridized algorithm examples of TLBO with search techniques are given in Table 1. A brief overview on the prominent examples will be provided in the following.

div.head: Table 1 Examples of developed hybrid TLBO algorithms with search techniques
Hybrid strategies Literatures
div.p: TLBO + Variable neighborhood search [97,103] TLBO + population reconstruction operation+ neighborhood search strategies [98,99] TLBO + CA-based approach +local unimodal sampling [100] TLBO + Nelder-Mead simplex algorithm-based local improvement [101] TLBO + Multi-meme learning based on meta-Lamarckian [102] TLBO + Support vector machine [104] TLBO + Local search function [105] TLBO + Simulated annealing operator [91] TLBO + Robust tabu search [106] TLBO + Gaussian sampling learning [107,108] Xie et al proposed an effective hybrid TLBO variant with a variable neighborhood search (VNS) [97]. To enforce the global search ability, after the teaching and learning phases, the crossover operator was randomly selected from two crossover operators so as to generate a pair of new learners. Then, variable neighborhood search with the simulated annealing operation was employed to exploit the individual obtained by TLBO. Furthermore, when the best learner was not improved and was in a stagnant state after a certain number of successive iterations, the population would be re-initialized, i.e., half of the learners were taken from the best learners generated in the novel TLBO memetic algorithm (TLBO-MA) [102]. In the proposed TLBO-MA, conservation of information inspired operator was introduced to enrich learning behaviors by considering both its own experience and its classmates' experience so as to improve the exploitation ability, and the multi-meme learning based on meta-Lamarckian was introduced to strengthen the promising refined region. Tang et al proposed a hybrid TLBO (HTLBO) approach by combining TLBO, crossover operator and variable neighborhood search (VNS) [103]. In HTLBO, the crossover operator was introduced to increase the search speed and enhance global search, and VNS with seven neighborhood operators was introduced to enhance the local search ability. Das and Padhy developed a novel hybrid model using TLBO and a support vector machine [104]. González-Álvarez et al presented a novel algorithm based on TLBO combined with a local search function specialized to predict common patterns in sets of protein sequences [105]. In Ref. [91], Simulated annealing operator was introduced into TLBO to prevent the individual seriously damaged. Dokeroglu introduced robust tabu search into TLBO so as to explore the solution space of each learner after the teaching and learning phases [106]. In addition, duplicate solutions were removed with randomly generated learners, and stagnation prevention procedure was employed when the teacher was not improved in a certain successive generations.

Zou et al developed a new bare-bones TLBO variant (BBTLBO) [107]. In BBLBO, a ring neighborhood topology was introduced and Gaussian sampling learning with ring topology was combined with the teaching phase learning strategy of the original TLBO with ring topology the teaching phase, and learners improved their knowledge levels by the learning phase learning strategy of the original TLBO or the new neighborhood search strategy in the learning phase. Ghasemi et al proposed novel Gaussian bare-bones TLBO approach (GBTLBO) and its extended version (MGBTLBO) [108]. In GBTLBO, the Gaussian sampling mutation strategy was substituted with the learning strategy of the teaching and learning phases in the original TLBO. In MGBTLBO, learners in the teaching phase select randomly the teaching phase learning strategy of the original TLBO or the Gaussian mutation strategy to enhance global search ability and speed up convergence, and learners in the learning phase select randomly the learning strategy based on four random learners or the Gaussian mutation strategy.

div.head: Hybridization of TLBO with other optimization algorithms
div.p: A few prominent hybridized algorithm examples of TLBO with other optimization algorithms are given in
div.formula: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T Table 2.
div.p: A brief overview on the prominent examples will also be provided in the following.

div.head: Table 2 Examples of developed hybrid TLBO algorithms with other optimization algorithms
Hybrid strategies Literatures
div.p: TLBO + Differential Evolution (DE) [109][110][111][112][113] TLBO + Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) [114][115][116] TLBO + Black Hole Algorithm (BHA) [117] TLBO + Genetic Algorithm (GA) [118] TLBO + Grtificial Bee Colony (ABC) [119] TLBO + Gravitational Search Algorithm (GSA) [120] TLBO + Artificial Bee Colony (ABC) + Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) [121] TLBO + Cuckoo Search Algorithm (CSA) [122,123] TLBO + Harmony Search Algorithm (HS) [124] To maintain the diversity of population and improve the global search ability, Wang et al developed a hybrid TLBO variant with DE (TLBO-DE) [109]. In TLBO-DE, learners improved knowledge levels by the random hybridization of the original learning method and the differential learning. Ghasemi et al merged two algorithms of modified TLBO and double DE algorithm to form a new hybrid optimization algorithm (MLTA-DDE) [110]. In MLTA-DDE, after employing the teaching phase of the original TLBO, if knowledge levels of learners did not change better, learners were moved towards the teacher by walking with a rand step and random direction. If knowledge levels of learners did not change better through moving to the teacher, learners were entered into DDE algorithm as the initial population. After employing the learning phase of the original TLBO, if knowledge levels of learners did change better, learners were entered into DDE algorithm as the initial population. Zou et al extended a TLBO variant with differential learning (DLTLBO) [111]. In DLTLBO, to balance the exploration and the exploitation, a teaching phase learning strategy on basis of neighborhood search was employed to generate a trial vector, while a differential learning was introduced to generate another trial vector. Then the crossover operation between these two trial vectors was employed to generate new learners so as to enhance the diversity of population. Dib and Boumhidi also extended a hybrid TLBO algorithm with DE [112]. In proposed algorithm, two mutant vectors were generated by the teaching phase learning of the original TLBO and differential learning based on DE/rand/1, and then the crossover operator between these two mutant vectors was executed to enhance the potential diversity of population. Inspired by the ensemble learning, Turgut and Coban employed a hybrid TLBO-DE algorithm [113]. In the proposed algorithm, an ensemble of mutation strategies including DE/best/1 and DE/best/2 was used to replace the learning phase learning method. In addition, chaotic sequences generated by the Logistic map were used to replace uniformly distributed random numbers (i.e., r in Eq.2) so as to improve the global search ability and speed up convergence of the algorithm.

Lim and Isa proposed a teaching and peer-learning PSO (TPLPSO) algorithm [114]. In TPLPSO, learning process consists of the teaching and peer-learning phases. In the teaching phase, the PSO learning strategy based on their historical best and the global best information was employed to generate new learners. When learners did

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: not improve their knowledge levels, they would employ the peer-learning phase. That is, these learners selected respectively their exemplar learners by the roulette wheel selection technique and then they learn new knowledge from their exemplar learners. In addition, a stagnation prevention strategy was employed to avoid the premature convergence. Lim and Isa further developed a bidirectional teaching and peer-learning PSO (BTPLPSO) [115]. In BTPLPSO, the teaching and peer-learning phases of TPLPSO were used to generate new learners. In addition, when learners can be improved successfully after these two phases, an orthogonal experimental design-based elitist learning strategy was employed to further improve the teacher's knowledge level. In order to promote the diversity and improve search ability of PSO, Cheng et al proposed a novel hybrid swarm optimization algorithm (HTL-PSO) [116]. In HTL-PSO, a modified TLBO (MTLBO) is proposed by integrating the teaching and learning phases into one learning phase to make use of the advantage of two phases and reduce evaluation complexity. PSO was employed as the main search and MTLBO was invoked periodically as auxiliary search technique in HTL-PSO evolution.

Azizipanah-Abarghooee presented gradient-based modified TLBO variant with black hole algorithm (MTLBO-BH) [117]. In MTLBO-BH, the teaching phase was integrated with black hole algorithm and the learning phase was replaced with a new self-adaptive wavelet mutation. By combining the specialties of conventional GA and TLBO, Güçyetmez and Çam developed a new hybrid optimization approach (G-TLBO) [118]. GA was used to provide the best learners to TLBO so that the total running time of the proposed algorithm decreases substantially. Chen et al proposed a new hybrid approach of TLBO and ABC (TLABC) to balance the exploration and the exploitation during the iterative evolution process [119]. TLABC adopted three hybrid approach (HSTL) [124]. In HSTL, a modified teaching-learning operator was employed according to a probability TLP. In the teaching phase, the mean individual was replaced with the mean of the current learner and the worst learner from the population, and in the learning phase, each learner learned from the advantages between the other two learners selected randomly.

div.head: TLBO in complex optimization scenarios
div.p: Researchers have extended TLBO into many complex optimization scenarios such as constrained optimization, multi-objectives optimization and dynamic optimization. This section provides an overview of the TLBO and its variants developed to deal with such optimization scenarios.

div.head: Constrained optimization
div.p: Most of real-world optimization problems are subject to various constraints. Due to the existence of various constraints, these problems are attempted to find a solution that not only was optimal, thus making them difficult to be dealt with. By introducing some mechanisms to tackle constraints, various techniques have been widely developed to solve diverse constrained optimization problems (COPs) [125][126][127][128][129].

The first known extension of TLBO to constrained optimization problems was developed by Rao in [21]. A tournament selection operator based on Deb's heuristic constrained handling was adopted to deal with constraints of the problems. Deb's heuristic constrained handling was also introduced into an elitist TLBO by Rao and Patel for solving complex constrained optimization problems [130]. Rao et al investigated TLBO with different constraint handling techniques such as superiority of feasible solutions, self-adaptive penalty, ε-constraint, stochastic ranking and ensemble of constraints [131]. To handle the coordination constraints, a transformation scheme was adopted by Singh et al to obtain the weighted sum total operating time of all primary relays and coordination time margin between backup and primary relay pairs [132]. Kalage and Ghawghawe also extended a modified adaptive TLBO to deal with this problem [133]. Kumar employed TLBO to deal with mechanical constrained design problems in his dissertation by introducing a penalty term into the objective function [134].

Roy applied TLBO for short-term hydrothermal scheduling problem [135]. Rao and Patel developed a multi-objective improved TLBO algorithm with the superiority of the feasible solution method for constrained optimization problems [136]. Arya and Koshti adopted a modified TLBO for anticipatory load shedding for line overload alleviation [137]. For inequality constraints, when two vectors satisfy inequality constraints, the individual with a better fitness value wins; otherwise, the individual with a least mean violation of inequality constraints wins. By transforming a constrained optimization problem into an unconstrained one, Huang et al adopted a new hybrid algorithm for three engineering design problems [123]. Yu et al introduced the adaptive fitness transformation scheme to remain some feasible learners with the better fitness values and infeasible learners with small fitness values and slight constraint violations during the iterative evolution processes [89].
Farshchin et al extended a new multi-class TLBO variant to deal with truss design with frequency constraints [90].
To account for infeasible truss designs, a cumulative penalty was introduced and it was in proportion to the

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: amount of frequency constraint violations. The final objective function with penalty term was a result of the value of the objective function multiplied by this cumulative penalty. Verma et al presented TLBO to solve congestion management problem with various security constraints [138]. In the proposed approach, the equality constraints are dealt effectively during Newton-Raphson power flow, the real power and reactive power inequality constraints were respectively dealt during the iterative processes and the load flow solution, and other inequality constraints were considered as quadratic penalty functions. A non-dominated sorting TLBO was employed to solve multi-objective optimization problems in the fused deposition modeling process [139]. In proposed algorithm, non-dominance sorting and crowding distance sorting were utilized to ensure learners toward true Pareto front as well as have a good distribution of the learners, and a constrained dominance concept was utilized to effectively handle the constraints. Tang et al presented a new TLBO approach with a variable neighborhood search to deal with the stochastic two-sided assembly line balancing problem with multiple constraints [103]. In the proposed approach, the priority-based decoding procedure was utilized to deal with all constraints by adjusting the priority value successively. In Ref. [140], TLBO was utilized to derive crisp weights of a constrained non-linear optimization model from fuzzy pairwise comparison matrices in analytic hierarchy process. Jia and Li applied TLBO with uniform design to constrained optimization problems [141]. In the proposed algorithm, feasible search strategy was introduced. What's different from Deb's heuristic constrained handling is that non-dominated strategy was adopted to select the best one when the learners were infeasible. Tembhurne and Shrimankar applied TLBO for constrained hyper-spectral unmixing [142]. In the proposed approach, clipping operations were used to manage abundance sum to one constraint and abundance non-negative constraint.

div.head: Multi-objective optimization
div.p: Many multi-objective optimization problems (MOPs) in the real world have conflicting objectives, and the major task in multi-objective optimization (MOO) is to gain a well-distributed non-dominated solution set as closely as possible to Pareto front (PF). Multi-objective optimization algorithms mainly include three classes:

Pareto dominance based, performance indicator based and decomposition based approaches [143,144]. Due to its population-based stochastic optimization characteristics, TLBO has been developed to deal with MOPs.

Niknam et al developed a new multi-objective TLBO approach with the dominance concept [61]. An external repository was used to store and manage all non-dominate solutions during the iterative evolution process. Hoseini et al developed a new multi-objective TLBO variant with the dominance concept and the external repository [145].

Niknam et al extended a new multi-objective TLBO approach [146]. In the proposed algorithm, all design variables were mapped to the phase angles, an external archive repository was utilized to store non-dominated solutions, and the pruning based on the fuzzy clustering was introduced to control the size of the repository. More, a niching mechanism was adopted to direct learners to search the lesser explored regions, and a fuzzy method was utilized to select the better learners to enter into the next iteration. The similar multi-objective handling approach can be utilized in [147]. Zou et al developed a multi-objective TLBO approach with non-dominated sorting and crowding distance mechanism [148]. In the proposed algorithm, an external archive was utilized to store and
div.formula: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: manage the best learners so far. The teacher was selected according to the crowding distance value from learners with the highest non-dominated rank in the external archive. All learners were updated by the dominate selection operator instead of the greedy selection, and half of learners from the external archive and the current population were selected to update the external archive on the basis of non-dominated sorting and crowding distance sorting.

The similar multi-objective handling approach was also utilized in [149]. Quasi-oppositional learning and non-dominated sorting were introduced into TLBO to solve diverse multi-objective optimization problems [38][39][40].

The external archive based on a grid-based ε-dominance method was introduced into multi-objective TLBO variants to store and manage the non-dominated solutions found so far [67,136,150,151,152]. Lin et al introduced the fast non-dominated sorting technique and the crowding distance assignment method into TLBO to minimize both make span and carbon footprint simultaneously [153]. In the proposed approach, the teachers were selected from learners with the highest crowding distance values, and a selection operator was utilized to determine if new generated learners were accepted after the teaching and learning phases. Yu et al developed a new multi-objective TLBO variant [68,69]. In the proposed algorithm, the selection probability based on non-domination and crowding distance sorting was calculated and used to select only one learning phase for each individual at each iteration. The learner with higher rank will be considered as the teacher in the teaching phase and the selection operation based on the dominance concept was utilized to determine if new generated learners were accepted after the teaching and learning phases. Finally, half of learners from the current population and the generated population were survived into the next generation based on the fast non-dominated sorting and crowding distance. Selvam et al employed a peer enhanced multi-objective based TLBO approach [154]. In the proposed approach, a fuzzy set theory approach was utilized to select the best compromise solution. Yu et al developed a novel multi-objective TLBO with an individualized instruction and the non-dominated sorting [155].

The teacher was selected by roulette wheel selection according to crowding distance from learners with the highest non-dominated rank, and a selection operation based on dominance relationship between the current learner and the generated learner was utilized to determine if new generated learners were accepted after the teaching phase and the learning phase. In addition, a fixed-size archive was used to preserve and update the best solutions obtained based on the ε-dominance criteria. By introducing decomposition mechanism, Medina et al presented a multi-objective TLBO for reactive power handling [156], and Chen et al employed a new multi-objective TLBO for community detection in complex networks [157].

div.head: Dynamic optimization
div.p: TLBO has been also extended to deal with dynamic optimization problems. Zou et al developed a multi-swarm TLBO (MTLBO) for moving peaks benchmark problem [158]. In MTLBO, learners were partitioned into several sub-swarms to cover and track multiple moving peaks in the fitness landscape, and these sub-swarms are also recombined periodically to facilitate the exchange of information among these sub-swarms. Yang et al employed a self-learning TLBO (SL-TLBO) approach to solve dynamic economic/environmental dispatch problems [65]. In Ref. [159], a cellular automata(CA)-based approach was presented to evaluate and manage
div.formula: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: solutions during the iterative evolution processes, and then it was introduced into TLBO to deal with dynamic multi-objective problems. In the proposed algorithm, the population consisted of a certain number of classes, the teacher of each class is selected from the archive based on the approximated hyper volume values and learners of each class are selected randomly from the archive and the population according to a proportion. After employing multi-objective TLBO for each class, the polynomial mutation was executed for a few learners selected randomly from the population. Moreover, the CA-based approach was executed to evaluate and manage new generated

div.head: Engineering applications of TLBO
div.p: In real-world application areas, there are various problems such as data classification and processing [161][162][163][164][165][166][167][168][169][170], image processing [171][172][173][174], pattern recognition [175][176][177][178][179][180][181] and artificial neural networks [182][183][184][185][186][187] and so on. TLBO has been used in many applications in various fields. However, dividing TLBO applications into areas is difficult. Here, we provide an overview on some prominent engineering applications of TLBO. A few prominent examples of TLBO in various application areas are given in Table 3. A brief overview on the prominent examples will also be provided in the following.

div.head: Manufacturing and operation research
div.p: TLBO has found some applications in manufacturing and operation research engineering areas. TLBO was extended to deal with parameter optimization of modern machining processes [188][189][190]. Aich and Banerjee applied TLBO for the development of support vector machine learned electric discharge machining process [191].

Rao et al adapted TLBO for obtaining optimal parameters of squeeze casting processes [192]. Rao and Kalyankar applied TLBO for multi-pass turning operations [193], and Yildiz introduced into a hybrid TLBO for optimization of multi-pass turning operations [51]. Gautam and Pandey applied TLBO for Kerf deviations optimization in laser cutting of Kevlar-29 composite laminates [194]. An elitist TLBO was utilized to deal with multi-level production planning in a petrochemical industry [195]. Zamli et al develop a new fuzzy adaptive TLBO algorithm, and they applied this algorithm for optimization of generating mixed strength t-way test suites [73]. Tuncel and Aydin applied TLBO to solve two-sided assembly line balancing problem [196], and Tang developed a hybrid TLBO with crossover operator and variable neighborhood search to solve this problem [101]. Xia et al presented a simplified TLBO algorithm for disassembly sequence planning [197].

Xu et al developed an effective TLBO and applied it for the flexible job-shop scheduling problem [59]. An effective hybrid TLBO with VNS was proposed to solve flow shop scheduling [97]. Roy et al introduced quasi-oppositional learning into TLBO for optimal short-term hydro-thermal scheduling [37]. Keesari and Rao extended TLBO to solve job shop scheduling [198]. Baykasoğlu et al applied TLBO for flow shop and job shop scheduling [199]. Short-term scheduling of thermal power systems using hybrid gradient based modified teaching-learning optimizer with black hole algorithm et al developed a new hybrid gradient based TLBO for short-term scheduling of thermal power systems [113]. Abirami et al applied TLBO to solve maintenance outage scheduling in a power system [200]. Li et al presented a discrete TLBO for realistic flow shop rescheduling [201].

Shao et al introduced a novel hybrid TLBO with teaching-probabilistic learning mechanism for no-wait flow shop scheduling [98] and no-idle flow shop scheduling [99]. Zheng et al adopted TLBO to deal with multi-skill resource constrained project scheduling [202]. Shao et al presented an extended TLBO approach for solving no-wait flow shop scheduling [34]. Lei et al extended a novel TLBO approach for energy-efficient hybrid flow shop scheduling [203].

div.head: A C C E P T E D M
div.p: A N U S C R I P T

div.head: Mechanical and electrical engineering
div.p: TLBO has been also used to solve optimization problems in mechanical and electrical engineering. Rao et al

proposed a new TLBO algorithm to solve four different mechanical design optimization problems [21]. Kumar extended an improved TLBO to deal with mechanical constrained design problems [134]. Zou employed a multi-objective TLBO (MOTLBO) algorithm and employed MOTLBO for mechanical constrained design problems [148]. Roy and Bhui employed a multi-objective quasi-oppositional TLBO approach and applied it to economic emission load dispatch problems [38]. Bulbul and Roy introduced an adaptive TLBO to deal with nonlinear economic load dispatch (ELD) problems [46]. Yang adopted a self-learning TLBO approach and applied it to 5-unit economic dispatch and 15-unit economic dispatch [65]. Niknam et al presented a θ-Multi-objective

TLBO approach and applied it to 5-unit system, 10-unit system and 120-unit system in dynamic economic emission dispatch [139]. Banerjee et al applied TLBO for ELD problems considering valve point loading effect [204]. Durai et al adopted TLBO for economic dispatch problems and applied it to various test systems [205].
Basu employed TLBO for multi-area economic dispatch and applied it to three test systems [206].

Roy et al applied an oppositional TLBO method for combined heat and power dispatch [35]. Mandal and Roy employed a quasi-oppositional TLBO variant and applied it to IEEE 30-bus and 118-bus systems [36].

Mandal and Roy proposed a multi-objective quasi-oppositional TLBO variant for optimal power flow problems and applied it to IEEE 30-bus, 62-bus and 118-bus systems [40]. Ghasemi et al employed a hybrid TLBO approach for reactive power dispatch problem and applied it to IEEE 14-bus, 30-bus and 118-bus system [106]. A novel TLBO was developed for reactive power dispatch problem and was applied to IEEE 14-bus and 30-bus systems [117]. A new hybrid G-TLBO approach was presented and applied to a 19 bus thermal-wind-powered systems [118]. A modified TLBO approach was proposed for multi-objective power flow problem and applied it to IEEE 30-bus and 57-bus system [147]. Bouchekara et al employed TLBO to power flow problems and applied it to IEEE 30-bus and 118-bus systems [207].
In addition, TLBO was applied for distributed generation planning in distribution systems [54,208,209,210],

and it also was extended to multi-objective optimization approaches for distributed generation planning in distribution systems [39,144,145,154]. TLBO also was extended to deal with optimal planning of distributed energy resources in distribution system [211,212]. Niknam et al developed a new multi-objective TLBO approach and applied it to location of automatic voltage regulators in distribution systems [61]. Sultana and Roy developed TLBO for optimal capacitor placement in radial distribution systems [213].

div.head: Civil engineering
div.p: An interesting application area of TLBO is civil engineering. Camp and Farshchin employed the modified TLBO algorithm for the design of space trusses [62]. Cheng and Prayogo developed a novel fuzzy adaptive TLBO variant for solving structural optimization problems [71]. Savsani et al developed a new modified TLBO approach to deal with truss structure optimization problems with static and dynamic constraints [87]. A modified sub-population TLBO approach was presented by Tejani et al for optimal design with frequency constraints of

div.head: A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T
div.p: truss structures [88]. Farshchin et al extend TLBO to a multi-class TLBO for truss design with frequency constraints [90]. Toğan adopted TLBO for optimization design of planar steel frames [214]. Degertekin and Hayalioglu employed TLBO for sizing truss structures [215]. Dede and Ayvaz employed TLBO for structural optimization [216] and size and shape optimization of structures [217]. Dede applied TLBO for solve the discrete optimization design of truss structures [218]. Farshchin et al developed TLBO with a collaborative optimization strategy and applied it to size and shape design with frequency constraints of truss structure [219]. Patel and

Savsani employed an improved multi-objective TLBO variant and applied it to a plate-fin heat exchanger design [150]. Dede applied TLBO for solve optimum design of grillage structures [220]. Rao and Waghmare developed a multi-objective TLBO variant for optimization design of a plate-fin heat sink [221].

div.head: Electronics and control engineering
div.p: TLBO has also been extended to deal with optimization problems in electronics and control engineering.

Cruz et al introduced a parallel TLBO procedure and applied it to automatic heliostat aiming [93]. Zou et al also extended a new hybrid TLBO with differential learning and applied it to parameter optimization of Digital IIR Filter [111]. Singh and Verma adopted TLBO for parameter optimization of Digital IIR Filter [222]. Bouchekara and Nahas developed a modified TLBO variant and applied to electromagnetics optimization problems [223].

Elkholy and Fathy applied TLBO to optimal inverter voltage and frequency in a PV fed water pumping system without storage [224]. Lim et al developed a new hybrid algorithm and applied it to spread spectrum radar polyphase code design problem [112]. Ghazi and Ahiod proposed an efficient TLBO approach for the discrete routing problem in wireless sensor networks [225]. Sharma and Kumar proposed an improved TLBO-based DV-Hop localization algorithm for wireless sensor networks [226], and they also proposed a modified TLBO-based energy-efficient range-free localization algorithm in wireless sensor networks [227].

Sahu et al optimized fuzzy-PID controller by a novel hybrid LUS-TLBO so as to control load frequency in multi-source power system [100]. Mohanty employed TLBO to optimize sliding mode controller [228]. Sahu et al adopted a TLBO-based fuzzy-PID controller to automatic generation control in multi-area power system [229].

Barisal applied TLBO to automatic load frequency control in multi-source power systems [230]. Chatterjee and Mukherjee applied TLBO to optimize PID controller in the automatic voltage regulator [231]. Chatterjee et al adopted TLBO to realize small-signal stability analysis in wind power system [232]. TLBO was extended to automatic generation control in multi-area power systems [233]. Sahu et al employed TLBO-based PID controller to automatic generation control in power system using [234]. A modified TLBO variant was developed by Khanduzi et al for optimal control of Volterra integral systems [235]. Dib and Boumhidi extended a hybrid DE-TLBO algorithm to adjust optimally the parameters of the (PID-PSS) controller optimal H ͚ and PID control in the multi-machine power system [110]. Wang et al adopted TLBO for optimal targeting of nonlinear chaotic systems [236]. Yadav et al employed TLBO to optimize the parameters of the PID controller so as to improve the performance of the magnetic levitation system [237]. Burla developed a hybridized TLBO approach to high dimensional data clustering [239]. In the proposed, principal component analysis was utilized to reduce the dimension of the data, TLBO was applied to find the image fusion method for visible and infrared images [246]. A TLBO-based robust edge detection algorithm was proposed to obtain the edge maps of the noisy real life digital images [247]. Jin et al proposed a geometric image segmentation method based on TLBO [248]. A new multilevel image threshold method was proposed based entropy of histogram and TLBO for image segmentation [249].

In addition, TLBO has been used successfully in other various areas, such as thermal engineering [67,119,250], chemistry engineering [77,160,195], aerospace engineering [102], software engineering [149],
bioinformatics engineering [105,251,252], artificial neural network [49,56,79,253] and so on.

div.head: Discussion on future research works
div.p: Although TLBO and its variants have been empirically shown to perform well on many numerical simulation and engineering application problems, it still can be believed that some topics are worth investigating within the next years. 2) Discrete optimization can be found in all kinds of engineering. As pointed out in Section 3-6, TLBO has been used to solve optimization problems with discrete parameters and achieved some remarkable results of solving discrete optimization problems. Therefore, extending the scope of application of TLBO and designing proper discrete operators that corresponds to learning processes of the teacher phase and learner phase in the continuous domain is also a challenging issue for future research.

div.head: A C C E P T E D M
div.p: A N U S C R I P T

3) As pointed out in Section 5.2, TLBO has been used to solve multi-objective optimization problems and achieved some remarkable results. Many objective optimization problems typically deal with more than three objective functions. Therefore, extending the multi-objective variants of TLBO to solve many-objective problems is also a challenging issue for future research. 5) At present, most achievements lay particular stress on numerical simulation and engineering application, and theoretical analysis of TLBO family has still not made a considerable progress. Therefore, theoretical analysis should be strengthened in TLBO, and an appropriate mathematical explanation for TLBO model should be investigated.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: This paper attempted to provide an introduction and survey of teaching-learning-based optimization (TLBO) algorithm. It is obvious that only a portion of the literature could be referred to, and many papers had to be totally omitted. By our reviewing at these papers, we can observe that the core work on TLBO has mainly focused on enhancing optimization performance and extending application areas. Researchers have developed various TLBO variants based on modifications and hybridizations to improve the optimization performance of TLBO, and have successfully applied to various optimization areas.

Need to note that there is still much more to do in this area. Particularly, it is noteworthy that in TLBO, TLBO has an inherent origin bias within the teaching phase, and thus find optimal solutions with a higher success rate when solving some problems with optima lied in the origin [254]. As a result, TLBO often loses its effectiveness and advantages when solving some problems with optima away from the origin. Hence, some topics are worth investigating. It is clear that some modifications and improvements to the original TLBO are still important and necessary in order to significantly improve its optimization performance. A theoretical analysis of convergence properties and dynamics of TLBO needs to be investigated. In addition, TLBO should be extended to a wider range of applications such as optimization in discrete, dynamic and uncertain environments. We hope that this survey will be useful for readers interested in TLBO and its variants and their applications.

figure.head: Fig. 5
figure.figDesc: Fig.5 Two-level hierarchical multi-swarmTwo modified sub-population TLBO approaches were developed and applied to optimization design of truss structures[87,88]. Yu et al extended an improved TLBO algorithm to constrained optimization problems[89]. In the teaching phase of the proposed algorithm, learners were divided into several subpopulations based on their Euclidean distance, and each subpopulation evolved based on its own direction information in parallel independently to the promising area promptly. Farshchin et al developed a new multi-class TLBO algorithm (MC-TLBO)[90]. In MC-TLBO, several independent classes were generated from all learners and these classes employed a modified TLBO variant to explore diverse areas in the search space in parallel. Then a super class was constructed by the best learners from these classes to employ the modified TLBO variant. Chen et al extended a multi-class cooperative TLBO algorithm with simulated annealing (SAMCCTLBO)[91]. To make full use of

S C R I P Tprevious process, and another half were generated randomly. Shao et al developed a hybrid discrete optimization approach based on teaching-probabilistic learning mechanism (HDTPL)[98,99]. In HDTPL, the teaching phase and the learning phase was replaced with discrete teaching phase and discrete probabilistic learning phase. A population reconstruction operation was introduced to avoid falling into local optima and neighborhood search strategies with the speed-up methods were introduced to further improve learners' quality. Sahu et al presented a new hybrid algorithm called regular TLBO with local unimodal sampling (LUS-TLBO)[100]. To improve the local search ability of the original TLBO, Zhang et al developed an improved TLBO strategy with Nelder-Mead simplex algorithm-based local improvement[101]. By incorporating a multi-meme learning, Qu et al proposed a

learning phases. That is, teaching-based employed bee phase employed a hybrid of the teaching phase learning strategy of the original TLBO and DE/rand/1mutation operator, learning-based on looker bee phase employed the learning phase learning strategy of the original TLBO, and generalized oppositional scout bee phase employed generalized opposition-based learning strategy. Tefek et al presented a new hybrid approach of gravitational search algorithm (GSA) and TLBO[120]. GSA was employed in the global search space and then TLBO was employed in the local search space. In other words, GSA searched the whole search space to obtain the optimum point in each iteration. According to the optimum point, the new range of the search space was determined. Then, TLBO searches the narrowed search space to obtain the best solution. To achieve a proper balance between the exploitation and the exploration, Patel et al developed an enhanced TLBO technique[121]. Enhancement was developed by incorporating the searching technique of ABC and PSO in the teacher phase, i.e., the teaching phase learning strategy was replaced with the searching technique of ABC and PSO. The original learning phase remained unchanged.By making full use of the search ability of cuckoo search algorithm and the fast convergence of TLBO, Huang et al developed a new hybrid algorithm (TLCS)[122,123]. In TLCS, some learners employed Lévy flight to generate new learners, and others employed teaching-learning strategy of TLBO to generate new learners. In addition, a fraction of worse solutions were discarded and they were replaced with new ones generated by using the Lévy flight rules. By introducing teaching-learning strategy, Tou et al extended an improved harmony search A C C E P T E D M A N U S C R I P T

learners. When detecting any environmental change, a new population consisted of learners selected randomly from the archive, mutated learners of a polynomial mutation on some non-selected learners of the archive, optimum learners of a Nelder-Mead local search local search on the endpoints of the previous Pareto front, and random solutions from the search space. Furthermore, an extended version of CTLBO called VECTLBO is proposed to optimize solutions for each objective separately through a single-objective optimization method. By translating the original DOPs into nonlinear programming problem, Chen et al. developed a quadratic interpolation based TLBO for chemical dynamic system optimization [160].

Pattern recognition and image processingTLBO has been used to deal with the optimization problems in pattern recognition and image processing. Amiri adopted TLBO to deal with the clustering problem[238]. The proposed algorithm was evaluated by testing on four artificial data sets and six real-life data sets and the results are compared with those of other algorithms.

initial cluster centroids and k-means clustering algorithm is used to find the clusters. Murty et al applied TLBO to automatic clustering on large unlabeled data sets [240]. Kanungo et al developed an elitist based TLBO with k-means method for data clustering [241]. Kurada et al proposed a novel TLBO-based automatic clustering method for gene functional enrichments [242]. Panigrahi and Pattnaik presented a modified TLBO to deal with clustering problems on two real-life data sets [243]. Tembhurne and Shrimankar applied TLBO to abundance estimation in spectral unmixing of hyper spectral image [138]. Rao et al proposed new automatic medical image segmentation based on TLBO [244]. Satapathy et al proposed a new feature selection method based on TLBO [245]. Jin and Wang presented a novel TLBO-based

Pickard et al. conjectured in [254] that over TLBO's inherent origin bias within the teaching phase may result in inefficient exploitation when solving the rotated and shifted optimization problems. Therefore, it may be of interest to introduce the bias controlling techniques based on annealing schedule. Also it is worthy to investigate the effect of tournament selection instead of greedy selection.

Many real-world optimization problems are dynamic in which variables of search space and/or objective space change over time. Hence the optimization algorithms should can quickly and efficiently track the moving optima or moving Pareto front in dealing with dynamic environments. Therefore, it may be of interest to introduce incremental learning techniques or Prediction Strategies when the objective functions change over time.
